key_title: Key to the species of Myriophyllum

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Haloragaceae

source.author: Jeanes, J.A.
source.title: Haloragaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: From: Jeanes, J.A. (1996). Haloragaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Lower or submerged leaves always in whorls
All leaves alternate, opposite or irregularly arranged
All leaves in whorls
Only submerged leaves in whorls, emergent leaves alternate or irregular
Emergent leaves pectinate
Emergent leaves terete, lanceolate, ovate or oblong, entire or toothed, never pectinate
Emergent leaves glaucous, in whorls of 4–6, with 18–36 pinnae; plants with female flowers only
Emergent leaves green to reddish-purple, in whorls of 2–4, with less than 12 pinnae; plants usually with both male and female flowers present
Leaves often congested at tips of stems; mericarps shortly ovoid, smooth or sparsely papillos
Leaves not congested at tips of stems; mericarps cylindric, angular, coarsely and irregularly warty
Emergent leaves terete or lanceolate (more than 3 times as long as wide)
Emergent leaves ovate to oblong (less than 3 times as long as wide)
Stems usually papillose; all emergent leaves coarsely toothed; flowers and fruit in fascicles; stigmas mauve to purple
Stems glabrous or with crisped hairs; uppermost emergent leaves more or less entire; flowers and fruit solitary; styles white to pink
Stems usually with crisped hairs; emergent leaves in whorls of 5–8; flowering shoots fusiform
Stems glabrous; emergent leaves in whorls of 3–6; flowering shoots more or less cylindric, tip truncate
Plant aquatic or semi-terrestrial; emergent leaves usually in whorls of 3 or 4, sometimes irregularly so; styles pink fading to white; fruit reddish-purple, mericarps ovoid
Plant aquatic; emergent leaves usually in whorls of 5; styles white; fruit yellow-brown, mericarps cylindric
Mericarps oblong to ovoid
Mericarps cylindric
Mericarps ovoid, smooth to minutely papillose
Mericarps oblong, angular, coarsely and irregularly warty
Plant perennial; stems to 2 m long; emergent leaves more or less entire, becoming alternate on upper stems; mature mericarps with dense fine spines on dorsal surface
Plant annual; stems to 40 cm long; emergent leaves often lobed near base, all whorled; mature mericarps with 3 longitudinal ridges and coarse conical warts on dorsal surface
Submerged leaves strictly in whorls
Submerged leaves in pseudowhorls or arranged irregularly
Emergent leaves linear or terete; mericarps <1 mm long
Emergent leaves oblong to ovate; mericarps c. 1.5 mm long
Leaves all or mostly alternate or irregular
Leaves all or mostly opposite
Lower leaves pectinate
Lower leaves entire or trifid
Plant aquatic; sepals of male flowers absent or vestigial and triangular
Plant semi-aquatic or terrestrial; sepals of male flowers lanceolate to ovate
All or most leaves alternate; mericarps cylindric, more or less the same diameter throughout, dorsal surface with papillae arranged in rows
At least some leaves in whorls; mericarps ovoid, widest near the base, dorsal surface with evenly arranged papillae
Plant perennial or potentially so; stems prostrate, rooting at nodes
Plant annual; stems erect or procumbent, never rooting at nodes
Male flowers with sepals
Male flowers without sepals
Flowers and fruits in fascicles
Flowers and fruits solitary
Lower leaves pectinate
Lower leaves entire, lobed or trifid
Mericarps ovoid to cylindric, apex truncate
Mericarps teardrop-shaped, apex attenuate into the style
Leaves usually obovate to broad-lanceolate, some lower leaves occasionally broadly lobed
Leaves usually linear, lower leaves occasionally trifid with linear lobes
